questions.question: What is the significance of Planck's constant (h) in the context of black body radiation?

answers.a: It determines the temperature of the black body.
answers.b: It governs the relationship between the energy and frequency of the emitted radiation.
answers.c: It represents the total energy emitted by the black body.
answers.d: It defines the color perception of the black body.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the concept of black body radiation?

answers.a: The radiation emitted by a black-colored object.
answers.b: The emission of colored light by hot objects.
answers.c: The continuous spectrum of radiation emitted by an idealized object that perfectly absorbs and emits radiation at all wavelengths.
answers.d: The reflection of light by a black surface.

questions.question: What role does Planck's constant play in quantizing energy levels in black body radiation?

answers.a: Planck's constant determines the color of the emitted radiation.
answers.b: Planck's constant is used to calculate the total energy emitted by the black body.
answers.c: Planck's constant quantizes the energy levels of the emitted radiation into discrete packets called "quanta" or photons.
answers.d: Planck's constant regulates the temperature of the black body.

questions.question: Why is it essential to repeat the experiment with multiple trials when finding Planck's constant?

answers.a: To reduce the effect of systematic errors.
answers.b: To increase the intensity of the incident light.
answers.c: To minimize the dark current of the detector.
answers.d: To decrease the uncertainty in the temperature measurement.

questions.question: How can the accuracy of the wavelength measurement be improved in the black body radiation experiment?

answers.a: Using a light source with a broader spectrum.
answers.b: Decreasing the resolution of the wavelength measurement instrument.
answers.c: Increasing the size of the black body.
answers.d: Using a diffraction grating for wavelength measurements.
